DataSetTools.dataset
Class UniformXScale

java.lang.Object
  DataSetTools.dataset.XScale
      DataSetTools.dataset.UniformXScale
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
public class UniformXScale
extends XScale
implements java.io.Serializable

The class for "X" scales that consist of evenly spaced points along a a specified interval. The evenly spaced points are specified by giving the end points of the interval and the number of points to create.

Version:
1.0
See Also:
DataSetTools.dataset.Data, XScale, VariableXScale, Serialized Form

Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

UniformXScale

public UniformXScale(float start_x,
                     float end_x,
                     int num_x)
Constructs a UniformXScale object by specifying the starting x, ending x and number of x values to be used. For example, if the scale was to run from 0 to 1000 in steps of 10, the values 0, 1000, 101 would be passed to this constructor. The number of x values must be at least 1. If the number of x values is greater than 1, then the start and end x values must be unequal. If the number of x values is equal to 1, then the start and end x values should be the same. If they are not, only the start value will actually be used.

Parameters:
start_x - the starting x
end_x - the ending x
num_x - the number of x values.
See Also:
XScale
Method Detail

createUniformXScale

public static UniformXScale createUniformXScale(float start_x,
                                                float end_x,
                                                int num_x)
Static method to create a UniformXScale. This static method is used by the Operator that creates a UniformXScale.

Parameters:
start_x - the starting x
end_x - the ending x
num_x - the number of x values.
Returns:
a UniformXScale

getXs

public float[] getXs()
Get the array of "X" values for this XScale. NOTE: The array of values is generated on demand, not stored as part of the XScale object.

Specified by:
getXs in class XScale
Returns:
the array of "X" values. The array will have num_x entries. The "X" values are uniformly spaced and are calculated from start_x, end_x and num_x.

getX

public float getX(int i)
Get the ith x-value from this XScale.

Specified by:
getX in class XScale
Parameters:
i - The position of the x-value that is needed. This should be between 0 and the number_of_x_values - 1.
Returns:
The x value in position i in the "list" of x-values for this x scale. If there is no such x value, this will return Float.NaN.

getI

public int getI(float x)
Get the position (i.e. index of the LUB) of the specified x-value in this XScale.

Specified by:
getI in class XScale
Parameters:
x - The x value to find in the "list" of x values represented by this x scale.
Returns:
The position "i" in the list of x-values, where the specified x occurs, if it is in the list. If the specified x is less than or equal to the last x in the "list", this function returns the index of the first x that is greater than or equal to the specified x. If the specified x value is above the end of the x scale, the number of points in the x scale is returned. This is the index of the Least Upper Bound (chosen from the list of values in the XScale) for the specified x_value.

getStep

public double getStep()
Get the separation between successive x values for this XScale.

Returns:
The distance between two successive x values in this XScale.

extend

public XScale extend(XScale other_scale)
Constructs a new UniformXScale that extends over the smallest interval containing both this XScale and the specifed XScale. The spacing between points is the same as for the current XScale and the start_x of the new XScale is choosen so that the division points of the current XScale are still used.

Specified by:
extend in class XScale
Parameters:
other_scale - The x scale that is used to extend the current XScale
Returns:
A new UniformXScale is returned that covers the union of the intervals covered by the current XScale and the other XScale.

restrict

public XScale restrict(ClosedInterval interval)
Constructs a new XScale that is the restriction of the current XScale to the intersection of the ClosedInterval and the interval of the current XScale. If the intersection is empty, this method returns null.

Specified by:
restrict in class XScale
Parameters:
interval - the interval the XScale is restricted to.
Returns:
A new XScale of the same type ( Uniform or Variable ) as the current XScale is returned if the intersection is non-empty, or null if the intersection is empty.

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
